answerText: "Little Gidding"[10] "Little Gidding" is the last of this set of poems, in which it follows "Burnt Norton," "The Dry Salvages," and "East Coker."
heading: Missiles of October |2011 | 8 | 7 | Literature | American | College
subject: Literature
question: Question: One part of this poem asks "Why should we celebrate / These dead men more than the dying," then continues on to say that the dead "Accept the constitution of silence." For 10 points each: [10] Name this poem whose elemental imagery includes "the communication / of the dead is tongued with fire beyond the language of the living."
